titleproper.value: Guide to the Robert Colodny Papers <num>ALBA.211</num>

author.value: Collection processed by Jessika Drmacich and Wendy Scheir, 2004

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

addressline: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace
        <date>2017-09-07T15:47:56</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

abstract.value:
Robert Colodny (1915-1997) fought with
        the Abraham Lincoln Brigade in the Spanish Civil War. He returned to the U.S. in 1938 with a
        severe head injury. He recovered and served in with the U.S. Army in Alaska during World War
        II. Colodny received his Ph.D. in history and philosophy in 1950 and joined the faculty of
        the University of Pittsburgh in 1959. In 1961, a Pennsylvania State representative accused
        Colodny of being a Communist sympathizer, jeopardizing his faculty position at the
        University of Pittsburgh. After a HUAC hearing and a University inquiry, Colodny was cleared
        and his position secured. This collection documents Colodnyâ€™s writings from World War II;
        his work as a writer and editor of academic, political and historical material; his
        correspondence and activities with the Veterans of the Abraham Lincoln Brigades (VALB); and
        his lifelong involvement in a range of progressive causes.

p.value:
Materials are open to researchers. Please contact the Tamiment Library & Robert F.
        Wagner Labor Archives for more information and to schedule an appointment,
        tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu or 212-998-2630.

Published citations should take the following form: <lb/><lb/>Identification of item, date;
        Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number; <lb/>Tamiment Library/Robert
        F. Wagner Labor Archives <lb/>Elmer Holmes Bobst Library <lb/>70 Washington Square South
        <lb/>New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.

<list>
          <item><title render="italic">The Struggle for Madrid: The Central Epic of the Spanish
              Conflict, 1936-37</title>(New York: Paine-Whitman, 1958)</item>
          <item><title render="italic">Spain: The Glory and the Tragedy</title>(New York: Humanities
            Press, 1970)</item>
          <item><title render="italic">Spain and Vietnam: The Fight for Freedom</title>(New York :
            Veterans of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade, 1967)</item>
        </list>

This series is comprised of original issues of <title render="italic">The Adakian</title>,
        the newsletter produced and written by Colodny and Dashiell Hammett in Alaska during World
        War II, as well as typescripts for radio shows broadcast on July 4th and V-J Day, 1945. Also
        in this series is a scrapbook of news clippings dating principally from 1961, when Colodny
        was under investigation by HUAC; two videotaped talks by Colodny; and an undated audio-tape
        of a Teach-In.
